So, is it correct to pursue a mass market strategy for the Australian market?
I don't think it excludes all regions of the country, for the time to be successful this year a retailer operates across the length and breadth of the country.
Can you comment on what improvements there might have been in your demand based forecasting capability in the time that you've been here?

We've put a lot more effort into that area. We've sent a team in that area as well. We're working more closely with our suppliers. We've taken a number of suppliers and take the employees to the suppliers and actually had them working, and I don't think it's wrong help support their supply chain through to improve our forecasting efficiency to work with suppliers through our supply chain, both of them, on time delivery through the supply chain as well. And then through, into the stores, as I mentioned earlier, so there is quite a lot of work taking place, trying to tighten in those specific areas and improve our performance.
If you were to aspire to get the world's best soup and salad prices can you do it without being the low-cost operator?

I think you have to find the right balance between the costs that you save and the level that you invest. Selling can be profitable in any supermarket anywhere. And we want to make sure that we maintain a very strong cost-conscious ethic. We look to streamline the center and if our store positions have reduced significantly. But if we need to invest in stores, more better service and produce so, the growth will improve more efficiently throughout the organization as well. So all of those elements of have initiatives out to take place at the moment.
This different signage steep discounts, two or 300 discounts in stores. Does that work?

Elements of it have worked. And we will be looking to integrate a lot of our ideas into one Coles going forward. The whole point of that doing a number of different trails in different stores, as we can get learning of the different aspects, so you can actually test to see which – what element that what you are doing are working, or which ones you need to review. So there are elements in each of the stores that we've been trialing different things that which we'll integrate into part of our strategy going forward.
It's just that Ivanhoe doesn't have everything in it. I am just curious: is Ivanhoe it, or is the next one going to have a different iteration?
I mean Ivanhoe was never going to be it.
Okay.

The whole point of doing in store trial is that you put on the ground a number of different ideas, trials, isolate the elements of those ideas to make sure you get a better understanding of what works.
Okay. Thanks. That's good.
Let's say you refine your advice on that basis; that's the whole point of saying that we're going through an extended pilot and then we'll progressively roll from that based on success.
Okay. Thank you. A quick question for Guy. How is Kmart going to be different from Big W going forward?

I've spent a bit of time purchasing on the competitors around Kmart and I think the main thing where we're going to be focusing on is, we've got, as I said, this business, which is a sizable one compared with our competitors, has got costs in it that need to be pulled out, so, it came out originally ahead of this country about 40 years ago – as we actually hit our 40th birthday this year – wanting to be a low cost operator and selling on-stream products, as a low cost retailer. That's the part that's broken down within size of model. So I want to make that point is, it's not a bad thing; it's kind of about having a $4 billion business that's surely within its DNA to make money.

The second part is the opportunity within Kmart is that we have a number of consumers that walk into our business and walk out with nothing in their hands. So, I'll put right at the top of our list of to do with in part just that we need to do a much better job in satisfying our consumers. So the bottom line is we have many of the people that visit us each week and we are not satisfying them, and we have a cost structure for a business that's probably the largest format in Australia that is not correct. So my focus for now is Kmart and executing its model correctly, which is what its original intention was 40 years ago. And then let my competitors do whatever they think best, but low cost and I'm not being particularly fast about what type of floor or ceiling I've got. I think that consumers deserve a better experience in the store, and a product that is on trend and selling to them at the best possible price.

So just one follow-up, there Guy. The merchandise is the problem and that's why you've got large periods of time where you're not profitable, last year – your last year cost of sales would not be seasonal as you trail?

I wish you with just one item and if was just that merchandise that usually the math when you go from a $4 billion business that produces and net income of nil, if it was just one item then my predecessors would have picked that 10 times over the last four, five years. There is about, I don't know, critical elements that I've evaluated in the last 100 days, that have gone amiss with Kmart and whilst my first period of time at the store focused on what my competitor has done. I think that you can be sealed away and spend too much time looking at what they have done or haven't done instead of looking in your own backyard and my team have been very impressive. They will yell at you, tell you what went wrong in Kmart and they know there's someone listening to it and just picking the eight to 10 items and addressing them immediately, which is why I think I made the point that in the last month, we remove about $200 million worth of excess stock that has been sitting there for a good period of time, which is now gone. It's a little bit different than it's been with the package that came out in December, I think that have my own stimulus package. This is related to Kmart to get some things of outstanding value during the month of December.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
Thank you. Our next question is from David Errington at Merrill Lynch, go ahead.

Afternoon, thanks. Richard on – there are some questions on the Resources group, I am quite concerned about coal you made it outlook for that division. The first question is, you've always in the last two or three years at least presented the chart on coal production costs and what the cash production costs per tonne for product tonnes is. Can you give us an indication of what the cash production costs per tonne is in the first half '09?
Yeah. I will do that. David Stewart here – yes the costs are up about 30% year on year.
30%? Year-on-year?
Yeah.
And that was because you just had get the tonnes out of the arm onto the barge?

Well, we feel we have a philosophy of getting maximizing, trying to do in the period a clearly high selling prices. But in addition to that, we see that our costs have moved in line with the increase – we haven't seen increase in the costs compared to our competitor and we believe that we still maintain our position in the lowest quartile of costs for export at local cost.

Yeah. Stewart, because in your volume chart a question was asked for that. When you look at about 70% of your coal goes to Japan and Korea, although they are vast and now both those countries steel industries are in a sharp recession; it's not depression; it very deep recession. I am really intrigued as to how you are going to maintain production volumes? I mean there it's previously announced production cuts of at least is 10% some are saying it could even be higher. I am just really intrigued as to how you are not going to suffer, particularly when you got 35% of your tonnages of Global PCI which seems to be as one that gets absolutely smoked in the first weeks of a downturn and there has been rumors out there that some PCI producer selling out of Leicester was selling their products of thermal coal at 70 to $73 a ton to the Koreans.

Yeah. That's what's been said – wouldn't surprise me at all David. – Just looking at our export sale price that we've had so far, we're being very, very particular in terms of who we sell our coal to and to make sure that we are long term enough with those, direction that's strong and a long history. Our big target, particularly, is what we call the blue-chip consumers, particularly in Northern Asia. And while I agree in terms of general volumes there is no doubt that volume going ahead will be under pressure. But our view on that and that'll become clearer about next month or so as the coal prices and volume settle, but the impact on us will be probably a little less than what others are seeing. And that's a direct result of that marketplace that we export in, so we don't have huge exposures into that territory or what I call more difficult parts of India and Europe. Our customers are blue-chip and they are honoring their contracts with us.

Stewart, with the Stanwell royalty, it's really hard to forecast. Most of this would have come – we're about 200 million in '09, and there you pretty much saying it's going to be 100, 200 in '09. In '010, assuming that the currency stays at $0.65, and which I know, I don't want to say that you think the coal prices are going to drop to this level. But let's just assume that the higher pricing coal cost drops to 120 and your volumes are around that 6.5 million tonne level, what would the Stanwell royalty be under that scenario in 2010?

Look David, it's – we've given some guidance as to what the Stanwell rebate will be in the second half, and we're expecting the full year to come in somewhere between 180 and $200 million in total in our financial year. Next year will depend on a range of things – it will not only be the – what we call a semi-soft or the current real prices to determine the royalty. But also it will depend on exchange rate. So basically those two settle it, and it's probably a little premature, let's just say, to give you number until that comes clear. It Certainly my intention of the next Investor Relations update in April to give more guidance in terms of volume for next year. I mean that's the appropriate time to settle, when things are lot clearer as to demand, price and let's just say that would be over the next six to 12 months.

And that's true, but investors are probably buying or selling the shares based upon 2010 earnings and the expectation of 2010 earnings. And this is a really big swing factor. If we were to assume AUD1.65, which is not unrealistic, and if we were to assume 120 hard coking coal prices and if we were to assume that tonnages were at around 6.5 million tonnes, which are the three keys that give into the Stanwell royalty, would the royalty in 2010 be around of $350 million?
Certainly. There is no doubt in this case that the royalty would be north of $200 million ..
Yes.
So it would be just over of 200 million in 2010, but under 300, is that right?
I'm not giving you guidance here – let's make that very clear.

David, this is Gene here. We have given you clear guidance on the right sort of formula. And that's been produced for anyone who wants to look at a set of assumptions, taking into account the semi-soft coal price not our hedged coal price. They could make a reasonable estimate just using 1% --
The divestment of what you're likely to see, Gene, you've got a responsibility to say that market expectations are out of whack too.
And we would.

Okay. Well let's go to the next point I want to get at. Because I want to get over to this hedging, what's happened there, in particular with the closing out of your forward book. I think you've closed out US$400 million, which I think in your information pack is going to cost you $83 million in the second half ,and $85 million in the full year '010. And that's on the basis of trend market conditions. Now I would like to understand what actually happened there because my understanding was Wesfarmers's policy was, if you did only hedge against what was known for certain and that you would never make hedges against market conditions that could potentially change. So I would like to get an understanding as to what actually happened that's going to cost you 83 million in the second half and 85 million in the full year of '10.

David, I'll try my best answer to your question, but clearly in October, November at the time, we'd known that this global economic crisis would have a major impact on our second half of this year and entering to the next financial year. And as you know back then, in October or prior October, exchange rates were might be tough numbers, and then we saw that exchange rate fall to less than US$0.65. We also came to the realization that the expectation for coal prices going forward was going dramatically fall. And demand was clearly unknown in terms of what impact global will come across, we'll have on still might be going to grow their demand for taking so. So we had hedge positions and pricing, and reported that to the market on previous updates. And what we took a proactive step back in October and November and into December to close that difference between those losses and that was what we did through our different strategies.

But Stewart, then how you could close on that loss given that you only ever locked in what was known tonnages that were going to be sold at known prices to close out these losses to the extent of that as amount, you must have been taking speculative positions. And I note – Note 12 in your financial statements the change in cash flow hedge reserve represents the after-tax net movement in market value of effective cash flow hedges in '08, and comprised 391 million of interest rate swaps, and 341 million of foreign exchange rate contracts. This company looks to have lost close to $750 million on hedging, which is borderlining on whether you've been taking speculative positions or whether it's just mismanagement of currency positions. That's the way I am reading it at this point in time.

David, as you would know, and we've announced it previously, our hedging position is supposed to be one that's an average of 50% hedging for US dollar revenues over a five-year period. In order for those to lock in hedging for years two and three and four and five, you've seen our position on volume and exchange rates. So that's essentially the situation we were both really – the exchange rate has dropped dramatically in October and November. There was the global economic crisis that hit us severely and volumes were certainly under pressure and we have taken I think a proactive approach there to bring additional -

I will take it offline, Stewart, because I just don't understand how hedge losses can be this large and to this extent because from what Wesfarmers policy used to be of only hedging what was known contracts at locked-in, known prices, and I just can't see how you could make such a big loss or such a big nil of the hedging position.

David, that's not what our policy was, subject to two issues you raised. I mean, one, in terms of interest rates hedging, we hedged interest rate exposure; as we've indicated previously, we hedged about 50% of our debt profile and as we were required to by our bank and that total amount of $700 million you referred to and that will be the mark-to-market of that and that hasn't been realized. What will be put through the P&L is what is realized as interest rates fell, because that's the interest rate. Hedging on coal price hedge, what we've said is, we will typically have hedged 50% of our coal sales out five years. And when you do that, the only known contracts for volumes and prices are firm for 12 months, and then you have to make pricing assumptions for the following five years. We've always done that at on a conservative basis. And that's how we done it, but in these circumstances, because of the rapidly depreciating Australian dollar, we closed out the hedging.
Was there any cost in the first half, Richard, or is all coming forward in the second half and 2010?

To give you exact amount – by the way all your forecasts will have the hedge positions there both currency and interest rates. Because we've been very clear about the market what we've hedged in the past on what our position is. So I don't think it should change anyone's forecast, Stewart what was the first half of that -
$5 million for the first half.
5 millions. Okay. Okay and what about the interest rate closure that's in the second half as well, Richard?

Yeah, that will be in the second half and again, as I said, that will – what impact there is over the longer-term will be dependent absolutely on what our net level of debt is and what you construct there.
In your Retail outlook – your retail upside in the equity placement is that – I am hearing that that's going very well. Have you revised your expectation that it's going to be staying the same.
Yeah, we'd expect it to be more than 15% as of this coming Friday [February 20, 2009]. We would receive about $200 million. Some of that is over-subscription, some of that is [inaudible].
What would you estimate it to be?
I don't know.
Okay. If you get a high on that, will that mean that more interest rate cost – closure cost will have to come through?
Yeah.
Thanks Richard. Thanks Stewart.
Thanks.
Thank you. Next is Lindy Newton of UBS. Go ahead.

Hi. I just had question regarding in Coles, I understand that the house brand review in now complete. I just wondered what the outcome was there, are you targeting a certain percent of sales from your house brand products? Are you rationalizing the range in terms of farm land reliance et cetera or what's actually happened?

You see, house brand is a very much integral part of our rates actually going forward. It gives us an opportunity for a broader return to the retailer, but also – we actually furnish much better value for the team so it's got to be satisfied with the products that you are selling, deliver good value in terms of quality. So we instigated a review is all the 2000 different products that we have under house brand and each one of those is going through a vast independent testing, that would be determined in how we see them.

I think that the results are actually very positive, we are very pleased with it. So the quality levels are actually very – compare very favorably throughout the brand or benefit that we have in our sales as well. We've also invested in developing a test that's in-house as well. So we're looking at developing actually sales of new products, reducing total costs, and so from that growth as well and the additional adequate. So we look at the primary product not just to test there well, but also we're looking to help our operations to grow where appropriate. So we are quite optimistic about the future of house brand in Coles.
So have you actually set any targets as to where you want to be in a couple of years?

Well, we know where we'd like to be in terms of overall potential. Certainly, the share percentages of house brands is fairly -significantly below that of retailers in the UK. But the real sort of drive on house brand product growth has really come over the last three or four years. And there is a danger you can try and take too much consumers too soon without taking them with you. That's what we constantly don't want to do. We want to make sure that consumer recognize the value themselves, so we'll be progressively looking to improve our penetration over time, but not get tangled up in it.

Okay. And just a question for John Gillam, please, in Bunnings. Of the 60% of products that's not produced in Australia and New Zealand, what's your sort of currency hedging there? I'm trying to get at when you might need to start raising your prices, to collar for the FX move?

I don't think the hedging is at all relevant. We work very hard to drive a very strong value position for our customers. And we mightn't be needing to raise the prices on key lines; there's a lot of pressure on our buying. Volumes of course, and we've been working in stores trying to keep costs down. So we are able to negotiate stronger brands. There are some cost increases. But from our perspective, what we focus on is figuring out how to deliver a lower price relative to competitors. And we're seeing competitors who are running significant cost inflation that enable us to strengthen our position to drive more volume. So that's interesting period of the game, so it's not quite simple as income and price increase not goes that broad. We've positioned – very strongly influenced around. But by far we've got cost base, I think, you're might going to see us in a position to driving value. These have very strong lever to win share in 2009.
Okay. That's all. Thanks.
Thank you and next is Emily Behncke of Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

Thank you. Sorry. Just a one quick question and just given the equity raising is pretty much complete, just wondering if you're going through actively big asset sales going forward, or is it a pretty fair assumption that those plans might be put on hold for a while?

Emily, nothing has changed. I can only say that if someone approaches us with an offer for our businesses we trust what shareholders would think about us. And that's our policy going forward, nothing's changed.
But the current environment obviously it doesn't lend itself to achieving very high prices I suppose?
That's a fair assumption.
Thanks.

I think that was the last question. So thank you all very much. If you've got any follow-up questions please contact me or Tanya or Jane. And I think you've seen some of the others look forward to it. Good afternoon.
